entries.text: Never invoke a raw terminal command if an MCP tool achieves the outcome.
entries.rationale: Tools provide structured, auditable operations and reduce risk of unsafe commands.
examples: Use powershell-command instead of direct shell.

entries.text: UNKNOWN or RISKY commands require explicit confirmed=true flag.
entries.rationale: Ensures deliberate human oversight before executing potentially destructive actions.
examples: Setting confirmed for a risky file deletion attempt.

entries.text: Always enumerate and prefer newly available MCP tools before considering any legacy approach or raw terminal usage.
entries.rationale: Ensures the agent immediately benefits from expanded structured capabilities, maximizing safety, auditability, and feature coverage whenever new tools are introduced.
examples: Run a ListTools / re-index step, then select an added tool instead of crafting a shell script.
Use a new diagnostic tool immediately after it appears rather than invoking a manual PowerShell command.
Re-learn tool schemas (list + cache) before executing related tasks after repo/tool updates.

entries.text: When new MCP tools become available, perform an immediate re-learning pass (list tools, cache schemas) before executing further actions.
entries.rationale: Guarantees the assistant leverages the expanded capability surface instantly and prevents stale planning based on outdated tool inventories.
examples: Detected new tool 'threat-analysis' -> call ListTools, update internal map, then use it instead of crafting manual powershell-command.
After pulling latest branch exposing 'server-stats', re-run tool enumeration before answering monitoring requests.
On receiving user notice 'new tools added', trigger tool refresh sequence prior to next operation.
